In a game that was hard fought
from beginning to end, the "Flying
Pentagon" of Washington College
trounced John Hopkins's quintet
last Friday to the tune of 45-28.
This victory avenge da 20-18 defeat received earlier in the season
from the Jays. In the previous
game both teams gave fine exhibitions of teamwork and close guarding. Last Friday night, Washington College gave another brilliant
example of team play while the
Black and Blue team was just fair.
Offense Centered About Gainor
Most of the offense was centered
about Gainor, Chestertown's elongated center man. He was both
the high-point scorer and the pivot
of the offense for this team.
Stevens, the Eastern Shoremen's
flashing guard, was again_ in good
form and scored nine points. Johnson, who usually plays guard,
shifted to forward in order to
cover Don Kelly and found the task
not a simple one.
Kelly Brothers Star
For the Jays, the only players
who seemed to be playing up to
their usual par were the Kelly
Between them, they
brothers.
scored nineteen of Hopkins's twenty-eight points.
Perhaps Friday the thirteenth
had something to do with the Jays'
poor showing or else it must have
been the after effects of the hard
struggle with St. Johns last Thursday night. At any rate, Hopkins
did not seem in top form.
Pentagon Passwork Brilliant
Right at the start of the whistle,
the Flying Pentagon began to click
perfectly. The passwork was brilliant, and the boys were cutting for
the basket like bolts out of the
ether.
They just couldn't be
stopped.
Gaynor was looping in one basket after the other. Stevens also
was setting a fast pace. Basket
after basket was being rung up
while all the Jays could do was try
to slacken up the attack by closer
guarding; but this only resulted in
personal fouls being called against
them. As a result of all this flashy
playing, the Pentagon had scored,
in nine miiutes, twenty points to
the Jays' one.
Kibler Removes Players
At this point Coach Kibler removed a few of the varsity players
for a respite. The Black and Blue
took advantage of this opportunity; but before they could function
properly, the half ended. Score—
Washington, 25; Hopkins, 10.
Both teams started the second
half with their regular lineups.
From then on the affair took on a
different aspect. Both sides began
to display fast passing and excellent guarding. The Chestertown
boys were playing as good as ever;
but no longer were they able to
dazzle Hopkins.
The Kelly brothers began to
Click and the rest of the team followed suit, but the gap was too
Wide. As the result the Flying
Pentagon eked out a well-deserved
victory.

Levy And Stone Comprise
Committee
A meeting of the Cage Fund
Committee, recently appointed by
Frank Cone, president of the Varsity Club, will be held today at 12.30.
The object of this committee, which
includes Heinzerling, Towbin, Yellott, Neu, Levy, and Stone is to discuss means of approaching the student body for the purpose of getting pledges to the cage fund.
Fund Begun In 1928
The committee has on hand some
funds from previous years as well
as pledges from 1928, the year
the Cage Fund was begun in the
University. The organization's goal
is 100 per cent pledges on the campus. The committee will act as advisers to -the Varsity Club which
will be in charge of the Pledge drive.
At the present time the committee
has several ideas as to the best
means of approaching the student
body. After today's meeting the
best plan will have been decided
upon and immediate action will follow.

EDITORIALS
The Perfect Day
Amidst much so-called "mud
slinging" and bulldozing of freshmen, another disagreeable period
known as pledge day has passed.
All the bad traits of each fraternity
man on the campus have' been
brought to light and discussed at
length. Any scandal that has taken
place at Hopkins during the past
ten years, has been told and retold
within the last twenty-four hours,
and a few imaginary ones created
as well. Freshmen have probably
formed the opinion that the joining of a fraternity is the most important step in their college life.
We hope that the Interfraternity
Board will seriously consider - abolishing the present system. To avoid
all this unpleasantness, it would
merely be necessary for the bids to
be placed in the post office boxes of
the freshman at the beginning of
the silent period, and allow the
first year men to make their own
decisions.

The Newspaper News
By some very sad mistake a rumor to the effect that the authorities had decided to do away with
intercollegiate football, slipped out
two weeks. In the first place this
rumor never should have leaked
out, but having leaked out, something should have been done, at
least to keep the tongues on the
campus quiet and let the papers
thrash around among themselves
until they should have found they
had no facts upon which to base
their articles.
Since the word got out that we
had taken the drastic step lots of
to-do has been made. Resolutions
have been adopted by bodies, petitions have been signed pro and con.
The papers of our city and other
large cities throughout the country
have taken up the story, enlarged
upon it to such an extent that it
has been said one paper spread on
its front page "HOPKINS TO

SEVER ALL INTER-COLLEGIATE RELATIONS."
—0—
This absurd situation must end
somewhere. Already it has had its
effect uon the men who had planned
to enter college next year. Some
of the men, athletes and students,
who had planned to come to Hopkins, hearing about the non-athletic
ideas for the future, have switched
over and now play to go to Maryland and St. Johns. This is the
same situation which occurred in
_1925 and 1927 just after the announcement of the intention of the
adoption of the Goodman Plan.
The latest development on the
campus has been a petition signed
by some twenty-five undergraduates in favor of the abolishing of
football. When the leader of this
document was questioned for his
reasons for taking such a step, his
reply was to the effect that we have
been having poor teams, so do away
with the sport. If this is the only
reason that can be given, it shows
that the Johns Hopkins students
are yellow. They're afraid to face
the music when they are defeated.
Why shouldn't we take a few defeats, keep our heads and come
back with a winning team with the
whole University and whole graduate body behind us?
—0—
If we do away with football, the
abolishionists suggest, we put up a
cage. But if we do away with inter-collegiate football, will the
graduates support a cage? They
will not.
The sooner we on the campus
curb these resolutions, these petitions, and give a definite statement
to the public at large that intercollegiate relations will be continued, at least until the undergraduate department has been done
away with, the undergraduate department of the future and the athletic teams of the future will mlprove.

EDITORIALS
The Perfect Day
Amidst much so-called "mud
slinging" and bulldozing of freshmen, another disagreeable period
known as pledge day has passed.
All the bad traits of each fraternity
man on the campus have' been
brought to light and discussed at
length. Any scandal that has taken
place at Hopkins during the past
ten years, has been told and retold
within the last twenty-four hours,
and a few imaginary ones created
as well. Freshmen have probably
formed the opinion that the joining of a fraternity is the most important step in their college life.
We hope that the Interfraternity
Board will seriously consider - abolishing the present system. To avoid
all this unpleasantness, it would
merely be necessary for the bids to
be placed in the post office boxes of
the freshman at the beginning of
the silent period, and allow the
first year men to make their own
decisions.

The Newspaper News
By some very sad mistake a rumor to the effect that the authorities had decided to do away with
intercollegiate football, slipped out
two weeks. In the first place this
rumor never should have leaked
out, but having leaked out, something should have been done, at
least to keep the tongues on the
campus quiet and let the papers
thrash around among themselves
until they should have found they
had no facts upon which to base
their articles.
Since the word got out that we
had taken the drastic step lots of
to-do has been made. Resolutions
have been adopted by bodies, petitions have been signed pro and con.
The papers of our city and other
large cities throughout the country
have taken up the story, enlarged
upon it to such an extent that it
has been said one paper spread on
its front page "HOPKINS TO

SEVER ALL INTER-COLLEGIATE RELATIONS."
—0—
This absurd situation must end
somewhere. Already it has had its
effect uon the men who had planned
to enter college next year. Some
of the men, athletes and students,
who had planned to come to Hopkins, hearing about the non-athletic
ideas for the future, have switched
over and now play to go to Maryland and St. Johns. This is the
same situation which occurred in
_1925 and 1927 just after the announcement of the intention of the
adoption of the Goodman Plan.
The latest development on the
campus has been a petition signed
by some twenty-five undergraduates in favor of the abolishing of
football. When the leader of this
document was questioned for his
reasons for taking such a step, his
reply was to the effect that we have
been having poor teams, so do away
with the sport. If this is the only
reason that can be given, it shows
that the Johns Hopkins students
are yellow. They're afraid to face
the music when they are defeated.
Why shouldn't we take a few defeats, keep our heads and come
back with a winning team with the
whole University and whole graduate body behind us?
—0—
If we do away with football, the
abolishionists suggest, we put up a
cage. But if we do away with inter-collegiate football, will the
graduates support a cage? They
will not.
The sooner we on the campus
curb these resolutions, these petitions, and give a definite statement
to the public at large that intercollegiate relations will be continued, at least until the undergraduate department has been done
away with, the undergraduate department of the future and the athletic teams of the future will mlprove.
